DataElement.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale of severity which indicates the degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, and the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

Concepts.definition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

Property.preferredDefinition: Describes how closely a cancer resembles normal tissue of its same type, and the cancer's probable rate of growth

Concepts.definition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

DataElementConcept.origin: MCL:Molecular and Cellular Characterization of Screened Lesions
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 2/28/22 mr Released per SME.   9/14/21 jk revised for use in PCA Lung CDEs.  10/1/19 jk created for MCL LabCas PCA-Genomic pilot.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit poorly differentiated or undifferentiated cells. They are generally expected to be fast growing and aggressive.

Concepts.definition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit poorly differentiated or undifferentiated cells. They are generally expected to be fast growing and aggressive.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit well to moderately well differentiated cells. They are generally expected to be slow growing and less aggressive.

Concepts.definition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit well to moderately well differentiated cells. They are generally expected to be slow growing and less aggressive.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a neoplasm is of borderline malignancy.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a neoplasm is of borderline malignancy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is poorly differentiated.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is undifferentiated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
